examples.en: Teach me about the effects of alcohol.
examples.ja: アルコールの作用を教えてください。

examples.en: This is the effect of chlorine.
examples.ja: これは塩素の作用です。

examples.en: Through the process of digestion, food is broken down into nutrients.
examples.ja: 消化作用によって、食べ物は栄養素に分解されます。

examples.en: Thanks to the effects of the medicine, the pain eased up.
examples.ja: 薬の作用により、痛みが和らいだ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>task</kanji> you're looking for a certain <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

What's the <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> of a <reading>saw</reading> on <reading>yo</reading>gurt (さよう)? What will the <vocabulary>action</vocabulary> of the saw on the yogurt do? Seems futile, but you're going to try anyway. For science.

examples.en: The establishment of this public corporation required the cooperation of many people.
examples.ja: この公社の設立には、多くの人々の協力が必要でした。

examples.en: Although it is called a public corporation, they have various operations.
examples.ja: 公社といっても、様々な事業があります。

examples.en: ”If I remember correctly, Yamada-san works for a government-run company." "What, is that a government-owned company?"
examples.ja: 「確か、山田さんは公社で働いています。」「えっ、あそこって国営公社なの？」

examples.en: The people here can automatically land positions as executives in public corporations through amakudari, even after they retire.
examples.ja: ここの人間は、退職した後も自動的に天下りで公社の役員になれるようになってるんですよ。

examples.en: These passenger rail services were operated by the Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa.
examples.ja: この旅客鉄道は、南アフリカ旅客鉄道公社が運営しています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji> is a <vocabulary>government-run company</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>government-owned company</vocabulary>. In other words, it's a company that's run by national or local government in the interests of the public.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are plans to build a new school in the area.
examples.ja: この地区には、新しい学校を建てる計画があります。

examples.en: Someday I want to build my own house too.
examples.ja: いつか俺も自分の家を建てたいな。

examples.en: Building a big bridge requires engineers.
examples.ja: 大きな橋を建てるにはエンジニアが必要です。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>build</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to build</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? <reading>た</reading>てる. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

examples.en: Dad is very proud because you became an architect.
examples.ja: お父さん、あんたが建築家になったから、鼻が高いのよ。

examples.en: This building was built by French architect Jules Lescas.
examples.ja: こちらはフランス人建築家のジュール・レスカスが建築した建物です。

examples.en: My house was designed by a famous architect.
examples.ja: 私の家は有名な建築家によってデザインされたんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 建築 is architecture. So, someone of <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>architecture</kanji> is someone who does architecture. They are an <vocabulary>architect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 建築 already.

examples.en: Currently, WaniKani has won great popularity.
examples.ja: 現在、ワニカニは大変な人気を呼んでいます。

examples.en: Please tell me the present address of the Tofugu office.
examples.ja: トーフグオフィスの現在の住所を教えてください。

examples.en: About how many emails are you getting a day now?
examples.ja: 現在は、一日に何件ぐらいのEmailを受信してるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: In the <kanji>present time</kanji> we <kanji>exist</kanji>. What time is it? It's <vocabulary>present</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>now</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>current</vocabulary> time!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The radio signal was weak, and noise was mixed in, so it was difficult to hear.
examples.ja: ラジオの電波が弱く、ノイズが混じって聞こえにくかった。

examples.en: My sister's brown eyes occasionally appeared to be mixed with green or yellow.
examples.ja: 妹の茶色の目には、時折、緑や黄色が混じって見えることがあった。

examples.en: The messages from the devil are a mixture of lies and truths meant to confuse us.
examples.ja: 悪魔からのメッセージには、我々を混乱させるために嘘と真実が入り混じっている。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>mix</kanji>, and you already learned its transitive and intransitive pair: 混ぜる (to mix) and 混ざる (to get mixed). 混じる is another intransitive verb, but it means <vocabulary>to be mixed in with</vocabulary>.

So how are 混ざる and 混じる different? 混ざる is used to talk about things that become mixed together as part of the same whole — like blended colors or intermingled groups. 混じる, on the other hand, is less about blending smoothly and more about something getting mixed in when it doesn't quite belong — static in your audio, scattered strands of gray in your dark hair, or even some random stranger sitting at your group's table.

You can remember this by thinking about how this out-of-place thing getting mixed in makes you want to <reading>jeer</reading> (じる): "Boo, get out of here! You don't fit in!"
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with 混ぜる, but here's a mnemonic in case you forgot:

Who doesn't want gray hair <vocabulary>to be mixed in</vocabulary> with their dark hair? Your <reading>ma</reading> (ま). Sadly for your ma, age and the stress of raising YOU have led to a lot of gray already starting to be mixed in. Poor ma…

examples.en: Wait, was that politician a conservative?
examples.ja: あれ、あの政治家って、保守主義だっけ？

examples.en: This country is strongly conservative, so change is slow.
examples.ja: この国は保守主義が強いので、変化が遅いんです。

examples.en: My parents are both teachers and extremely old-fashioned conservatives.
examples.ja: 私の両親は、二人とも教師で、めちゃくちゃ古風な保守主義者です。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that ism to people who want to <kanji>protect</kanji> and <kanji>conserve</kanji> their country so it stays just the way it is (forever). That's <vocabulary>conservatism</vocabulary> and they're <vocabulary>conservative</vocabulary> people.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the reading of 保守的 for the first half and then the regular kanji readings for the second half. Combine those things and you'll be a master of righteousness and / or kanji.

examples.en: That baseball commentator doesn't have a very good reputation.
examples.ja: あの野球評論家は、あまり評判が良くないんだよ。

examples.en: A well-known beauty in Portland works for Tofugu.
examples.ja: トーフグでは、ポートランドで評判の美人が働いている。

examples.en: This area was once a slum, but the government's gentrification strategy was successful and dramatically changed the living conditions.  Now it has an extremely good reputation.
examples.ja: この地域は昔はスラム街でしたが、政府の戦略としての居住地域の高級化が功を奏し、住環境ががらっと変わったんですよ。今は評判もすこぶるいいです。

meaning_mnemonic: When people <kanji>evaluate</kanji> and <kanji>judge</kanji> you at every turn, it means you have quite a <vocabulary>reputation</vocabulary>, and indeed <vocabulary>fame</vocabulary>. Wouldn't this be terrible if people evaluated and judged you 24/7? Having that kind of reputation or fame would be difficult.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This uses a slightly different reading from what you learned for 判, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your <vocabulary>reputation</vocabulary> is incredibly important to you, so don't let anybody know that you've been <reading>ban</reading>ned (ばん) on the WaniKani forums before. Wouldn't want anyone to find out. What, this is going to be published as a reading mnemonic on WaniKani?! What are you talking about? Oh sh-...

examples.en: Yesterday's concert was wonderful!
examples.ja: 昨日のコンサート、素晴らしかったです！

examples.en: The opening of that film and the camera work were truly magnificent.
examples.ja: あの映画のオープニングとカメラワークは実に素晴らしかった。

examples.en: A magnificent view extended out from the mountaintop.
examples.ja: 山頂には素晴らしい景色が広がっていた。

examples.en: "Don’t sell yourself short like that. You’re a magnificent woman."
examples.ja: 「そんな風に自分を安売りしないで。君は素晴らしい女性だよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>element</kanji> of <kanji>clear up</kanji> (like the sky clearing up!) is so <vocabulary>wonderful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary>. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. 晴れる is はれる. That's the reading you use here, though は goes to ば.

examples.en: The conversation got sidetracked.
examples.ja: 話が脱線しました。

examples.en: The train was derailed, but nobody was injured.
examples.ja: 電車が脱線しましたが、ケガ人はありませんでした。

examples.en: Sorry, I got sidetracked again.
examples.ja: すいません、また脱線してしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When something <kanji>escape</kanji>s from the <kanji>line</kanji> it should be on, that's a <vocabulary>derailment</vocabulary>.

脱線 can refer to train derailments (no surprise there), but often gets used figuratively to mean a <vocabulary>digression</vocabulary>, like in speech or writing. Do you ever derail conversations with your digressions?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How did you manage to break out?
examples.ja: どうやって脱走に成功したの？

examples.en: We built a fence to prevent the dog from escaping.
examples.ja: 犬が脱走しないように、フェンスを作りました。

examples.en: Apparently, our kid has tried to escape from school.
examples.ja: うちの子、学校から脱走しようとしたみたいなんだよね。

examples.en: The criminal, who had received a heavy sentence, broke out of prison.
examples.ja: 重い刑罰を言い渡された犯罪者が、刑務所から脱走した。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>escape</kanji> and <kanji>run</kanji> the hell out of there. Basically, you're trying <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to flee</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to break out</vocabulary>. Pretty simple.

脱走する specifically refers to escaping from a controlled or confined environment, like escaping from prison, a military base, or a guarded facility.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The だつ changes to だっ, though, so be careful of that.

examples.en: I didn't intend to evade taxes.
examples.ja: 脱税するつもりはなかったんです。

examples.en: Oh no, I might have been caught evading taxes.
examples.ja: ヤバイ、脱税してたのがバレたかもしれない。

examples.en: The tax evasion was at the direction of Mr. Mori.
examples.ja: 脱税は森氏の指示でした。

examples.en: When I was little my parents taught me to be a kind person, but they were arrested on charges of tax evasion.
examples.ja: 私は小さいころ、両親から親切な人になるよう教わりましたが、二人は脱税容疑で逮捕されました。

meaning_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>escape</kanji> from <kanji>tax</kanji>es? You scared of them? Huh? That's <vocabulary>tax evasion</vocabulary>, buddy. You're going to jail for that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The local train has just passed through a tunnel.
examples.ja: この各駅停車はちょうどトンネルを通り過ぎたところです。

meaning_mnemonic:
At  <kanji>each</kanji>  <kanji>station</kanji> someone keeps  <kanji>halt</kanji>ing the  <kanji>car </kanji>. What is this, a <vocabulary>local train</vocabulary>?! Yes, yes it is. You’re on a local train. People use it when they get on (or off) at the smaller stations.

If you’re not used to train travel, just remember that a "local train" is one that stops at every station on a line.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The police have a system to verify information in real time.
examples.ja: 警察には、情報をリアルタイムで確認するシステムがある。

examples.en: Wouldn't it be better to confirm with a lawyer?
examples.ja: 弁護士に確認してみた方がいいんじゃない？

examples.en: I was so relieved when I confirmed that our company finally got out of the red.
examples.ja: 我が社がついに赤字を脱したことを確認した時、私は胸を撫で下ろしました。

meaning_mnemonic: 確認 is confirmation. When that's a verb, you have <vocabulary>to confirm</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to verify</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help immensely if you know the word 確認 already as well.

examples.en: I often get my shopping done online.
examples.ja: 買い物はオンラインで済ますことが多いです。

examples.en: I went to the bathroom at the law office.
examples.ja: トイレは法律事務所で済ましてきました。

examples.en: What? Do you think just a "sorry" will be enough?
examples.ja: えっ、「ごめん」で済ますつもり？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 済む and how it means "to come to an end." This is like that, but slightly different. This is <vocabulary>to finish something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to settle something</vocabulary>, because this is when you're doing the coming to an end action. You can remember this because you're coming in to finish the score uno <reading>mas</reading> (ます) time. This is the last time.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with 済む, so if you know that you'll be able <vocabulary>to finish</vocabulary> this vocab.

examples.en: With this number of people, wouldn't it be more economical to take a taxi?
examples.ja: この人数なら、タクシーで行く方が経済的じゃない？

examples.en: Since I am in a difficult financial position, I’m working full time 5 days a week while also working part time 6 days a week.
examples.ja: 私は経済的に苦しい立場にあるため、週五日フルタイムの仕事をしているうえに、週六日パートタイムでも働いています。

examples.en: Although we do not have the financial means to do so, we try to save as much as possible in case of emergency.
examples.ja: 経済的な余裕は無いが、万が一に備えてできるだけ貯金をするようにしています。

meaning_mnemonic: 経済 is economics. So, something that has to do with economics is the <vocabulary>economic</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>financial</vocabulary> situation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

examples.en: I just can't understand why some people would skip such a fun committee meeting.
examples.ja: あんなに楽しい委員会の会議をサボる人がいるなんて理解できない。

examples.en: I was given a big job as chair of the budget committee.
examples.ja: 予算委員会の委員長という大役をおおせつかった。

examples.en: You should stop flip-flopping on important issues in the committee, it’s irresponsible. Everyone finds it annoying.
examples.ja: いい加減、委員会での重要な問題に対して意見をころころ変えるのをやめてくれないか。みんなにいい迷惑だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: There are member(s) of a committee (委員) all getting together to <kanji>meet</kanji>. This is the <vocabulary>committee</vocabulary> itself.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 委員 as well, since it's 2/3rds of the word.

examples.en: We elect a Tofugu Chairman every year.
examples.ja: トーフグの会長を毎年選挙しています。

examples.en: The government announced the date for electing the next leader.
examples.ja: 政府は次のリーダーを選挙する日を発表しました。

examples.en: Every year at our school, there's an event to elect the student council president.
examples.ja: うちの学校では、毎年、生徒会長を選挙するイベントがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Election</kanji> is 選挙 so when you make that word into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to elect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from 選挙 so if you know that you know this as well.

examples.en: Koichi is a man who’s filled with a sense of responsibility.
examples.ja: コウイチは、責任感のかたまりのような男だ。

examples.en: Tofugu's employees are all responsible people.
examples.ja: トーフグの社員は責任感がある人達ばかりです。

examples.en: He may have a strong sense of responsibility, but to me he seemed a little rude and selfish.
examples.ja: 彼は責任感が強いのかもしれないけど、私には少し失礼で自分勝手な気がしました。

meaning_mnemonic: 責任 is <kanji>responsibility</kanji>. If you add 感 you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is <vocabulary>sense of responsibility</vocabulary>. Do you have one?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Does this bus stop at that bus stop?
examples.ja: このバス、あのバス停で止まりますか？

examples.en: If it's bus number 29, it should come to this bus stop.
examples.ja: ２９番のバスなら、このバス停に来るはずですよ。

examples.en: At the bus stop, I accidentally got on the express bus.
examples.ja: バス停で、間違えて直通のバスに乗ってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is where the <kanji>bus</kanji> (バス) halts. It's the <vocabulary>bus stop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: For me, the biggest problem in the world right now is the stoppage of WaniKani sticker production.
examples.ja: ワニカニのステッカーの生産停止は、私にとって、今世界で一番大きな問題です。

examples.en: I try to pause videos during meal time.
examples.ja: 食事中は動画を停止するようにしています。

examples.en: My brother once went into cardiopulmonary arrest, but his heart started beating again after the surgeon performed a cardiac massage.
examples.ja: 私の兄は一度心肺停止にまで至ったんですが、外科医が心臓マッサージを施した後に、心臓が再び脈動しだしたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Halt</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji>. When something does this, it's in a <vocabulary>stoppage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Did Kawasaki City not lose power?
examples.ja: 川崎市は停電しなかったの？

examples.en: Why do I keep flipping light switches on and off if I know that there is still a power outage.
examples.ja: どうしてまだ停電してるって分かってるのに、電気のスイッチを何度も付けたり消したりしちゃうんだろう。

examples.en: Because of the blackout, all of the ice cream in the freezer melted.
examples.ja: 停電のせいで、冷凍庫のアイスクリームが全部とけちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>halt</kanji> <kanji>electricity</kanji> you experience a <vocabulary>power outage</vocabulary>. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That vampire is so negative about everything, it's getting on my nerves.
examples.ja: あの吸血鬼は、何事に対してもマイナス思考で、こっちがイライラしてくるよ。

examples.en: The vampire rushed back to where he sleeps.
examples.ja: 吸血鬼は、あわてて寝どこに帰っていった。

examples.en: That vampire bastard is seriously unforgivable! He told me that he wouldn’t even suck my blood because I am too much of a phony.
examples.ja: 吸血鬼の野郎、マジ許せねえ！俺の事、血を吸いたくない程インチキ臭すぎるって言うんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>demon</kanji> that <kanji>suck</kanji>s <kanji>blood</kanji>? What mythological creature can you think of that sucks blood? How about a <vocabulary>vampire</vocabulary>? Them Sparklzzzz!
reading_mnemonic: 吸血 should be easy for you to read. The 鬼 part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, き. Easy, no?

examples.en: I can't keep up with the speed at which young people absorb knowledge.
examples.ja: 若者の知識の吸収スピードにはついていけないよ。

examples.en: Our tenugui absorbs a great deal of liquid.
examples.ja: うちの手ぬぐいは、水分の吸収力がすごいんです。

examples.en: When plants get water, how long does it take for them to absorb it?
examples.ja: 植物が水分を取り入れる時って、どれくらいのスピードで吸収するんですか？

examples.en: If you want to be comfortable on your menstrual days, we recommend choosing a pad with a higher absorption rate.
examples.ja: 生理の日を快適に過ごすなら、より吸収量の多いナプキンを選ぶのがおすすめです。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>suck</kanji> something in and <kanji>obtain</kanji> it. Shhheewwwwww! When you suck something in and obtain it into your body, you have done <vocabulary>absorption</vocabulary> because it's been sucked inside of you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Can you issue the receipt again?
examples.ja: もう一度領収書を発行してもらえませんか？

examples.en: I’d like to return this, is that okay? Here’s the receipt.
examples.ja: すいません、これを返品したいんですけど、できますか？これが領収書です。

examples.en: I think you should really turn in your receipts to get reimbursed.
examples.ja: いい加減そろそろ領収書を出して、経費を払い戻してもらった方がいいんじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>obtain</kanji> some <kanji>territory</kanji>, so I want a <kanji>writte</kanji>n record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a <vocabulary>receipt</vocabulary>? Emailing one will do just fine.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That person doesn't have much income but always spends lavishly.
examples.ja: あの人、収入があまりないのに、いつも贅沢しているんです。

examples.en: When I opened up about my actual income, I got dumped.
examples.ja: 本当の収入を打ち明けたら、フラれたんだ。

examples.en: If I take the job overseas, my income will probably be half what it is now.
examples.ja: その海外での仕事に就けば、おそらく収入が半分になるだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: Please <kanji>enter</kanji> what you've <kanji>obtain</kanji>ed in here. We'll divvy it all up later. But we have to enter it all here so we know our <vocabulary>income</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is not real leather.
examples.ja: これは本物の革じゃありません。

examples.en: I processed the hides into leather in order to make a leather bag.
examples.ja: 革のカバンを作るために、皮を革に加工しました。

examples.en: Fugu bought crocodile skin sandals in Japan.
examples.ja: フグは日本でワニ革のサンダルを買った。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

<vocabulary>Leather</vocabulary> is the skin of a cow, right? How do you say "skin" in Japanese? Remember <reading>皮</reading> (かわ)? It has the same reading as that, and they're both skin, so hopefully that makes it easier to remember.

examples.en: Our revolutionary leader is a very understanding person.
examples.ja: 私達の革命の指導者は、とても理解がある人なんです。

examples.en: You are lucky to see the beginning of this revolution.
examples.ja: この革命の始まりを見ることができたあなたは、幸せですよ。

examples.en: The situation changed for the better after the revolution.
examples.ja: 革命の後、情勢は好転した。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Leather</kanji>'s <kanji>fate</kanji> is in the hands of a <vocabulary>revolution</vocabulary>. It's the leather revolution! Off with these normal clothes and on with leather ones!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: After washing it several times, the color of the leather has started to fade. Now I’m wondering if I was even supposed to wash it.
examples.ja: 何度か洗濯したら、皮革の色があせ始めたんだけど、もしかしたら洗っちゃいけなかったのかな。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Skin</kanji> <kanji>leather</kanji> is really just <vocabulary>leather</vocabulary> because leather is also skin. It's also <vocabulary>hides</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

examples.en: I am unemployed again.
examples.ja: また無職になってしまった。

examples.en: I became friends with an unemployed homeless man.
examples.ja: 無職のホームレスの男性と友達になりました。

examples.en: I was unemployed and couldn't pay my bills, so my gas and electricity were shut off.
examples.ja: 無職でお金がはらえずにいたら、ガスと電気を止められました。

examples.en: He would be the perfect husband, save for one thing - he has been unemployed for ten years.
examples.ja: 彼は完璧な夫ですが、一つだけ問題があるんです。十年間ずっと無職なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When the status of your <kanji>employment</kanji> is "<kanji>nothing</kanji>" then you're probably <vocabulary>unemployed</vocabulary>. You're experiencing <vocabulary>unemployment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What do you think of this workplace?
examples.ja: この職場、どう思う？

examples.en: My workplace is equipped with the most up-to-date computers.
examples.ja: 私の職場には、最新のコンピュータが備えられています。

examples.en: Apparently, I have a secret admirer at work.
examples.ja: どうやら、職場に私のかくれファンがいるみたいなんです。

examples.en: If you want to stay in this workplace, you’ve got to quit your habit of making everything out to be a big deal.
examples.ja: もしこの職場に残りたいのなら、物事をたいそうに考えるクセを無くしてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>employment</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is your <vocabulary>place of work</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>place of employment</vocabulary>. It's also your <vocabulary>workplace</vocabulary>.

Are you using WaniKani at your 職場 right now? Wouldn't that be funny.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

At your <vocabulary>place of work</vocabulary>, you "<reading>baa</reading>" (ば) to your coworkers as a greeting. Remember that town hall where you had to speak Sheepanese to the clerks? Well, it turns out your "baa" pronunciation was so good that they hired you. Now you can practice baaing all day, and get paid for it too!

examples.en: What profession do you want to have when you grow up?
examples.ja: 大人になったら、どんな職業につきたい？

examples.en: Do you work as a model, perhaps? You have great style.
examples.ja: あなたの職業って、もしかしてモデルなの？スタイルめっちゃいいよね。

examples.en: All WaniKani users know what Viet's secret job is.
examples.ja: ワニカニユーザーは、ビエトの裏の職業が何なのか、みんな知っています。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>employment</kanji> <kanji>business</kanji> is your <vocabulary>occupation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>profession</vocabulary>. What is your employment business?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I’m not a teacher, but I am part of the school staff.
examples.ja: 私は教師ではありませんが、学校職員です。

examples.en: The employees are studying to prepare for an examination too.
examples.ja: 職員達も、試験に備えて勉強しています。

examples.en: Our staff are all good at cracking eggs.
examples.ja: うちの職員は、みんな卵を割るのが上手なんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>employment</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji>s of a workplace are the <vocabulary>personnel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>staff</vocabulary>. Pretty straightforward!

職員 and 社員 are two similar terms, but have different meanings. 社員 generally refers to employees of private companies, while 職員 refers to employees who work in various fields such as civil service, education, government, non-profits, and more.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The man I met on the internet is in his thirties and has a job, but he is divorced and also has a kid.
examples.ja: 私がインターネットで出会った男性は、三十代で有職ですが、バツイチ子持ちです。

examples.en: In Japanese, we use the word "mushoku" to say "I am unemployed," but we don't use the word "yūshoku" to say "I am employed."
examples.ja: 日本語では、「無職」という言葉を使って「私は無職です」とは言うけど、「有職」という言葉を使って「私は有職です」とは言わないんだよね。

examples.en: Is it really such an important condition for marriage that your potential spouse be employed?
examples.ja: 相手が有職であることって、結婚するのにそんなに大事な条件でしょうか？

meaning_mnemonic:
To <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>employment</kanji> just means <vocabulary>having a job</vocabulary>. Wow, congrats on <vocabulary>being employed</vocabulary>!

有職 is a formal word for saying that someone has a steady job, as opposed to 無職 (unemployed). You'll often see it in official writing like surveys or articles.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you know any good job hunting websites?
examples.ja: いい求職のサイト、知ってる？

examples.en: There’s a lot of useful information for job hunting on this blog.
examples.ja: このブログには、求職する時に役立つ情報がたくさんのっている。

examples.en: Don’t worry about being unemployed. I’ve been job hunting for almost two years now.
examples.ja: 失業なんて気にするなよ。俺なんてかれこれもう約二年間も求職活動中だぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: Ugh, time to <kanji>request</kanji> <kanji>employment</kanji> again. Time to go <vocabulary>job hunting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The MP will not resign and will continue to be a member of parliament.
examples.ja: その国会議員は辞職しないで議員を続けるそうです。

examples.en: Since my boss clearly told me, "There are plenty of people who can replace you," I resigned from that company.
examples.ja: 上司にはっきりと「あなたの代わりはいくらでもいる」と言われたので、その会社を辞職しました。

examples.en: Mami was forced to resign for the crime of eating Koichi's bacon.
examples.ja: マミはコウイチのベーコンを食べた罪で辞職に追いこまれた。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>quit</kanji> your place of <kanji>employment</kanji>, you are putting in your <vocabulary>resignation</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>resigning</vocabulary>.

辞職 is a formal term that refers to someone voluntarily leaving their job or post in professional settings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Mom was as mad as an ogre yesterday, huh?
examples.ja: 昨日、お母さん、鬼のようにキレてたよね。

examples.en: Let's say that you actually saw an ogre.
examples.ja: あなたが実際に鬼を見たと仮定しましょう。

examples.en: Hey! Stop this weak act and show us your true form, you demon!
examples.ja: おい！下手な芝居はやめて正体を現せ！この、鬼め！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

<vocabulary>Demon</vocabulary>s are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the <vocabulary>"O" knee</vocabulary> (おに).

examples.en: The nurse always seemed to have a fake smile on her face.
examples.ja: その看護師はいつも作り笑いをしているように見えた。

examples.en: My husband is critical of my continuing to work as a nurse.
examples.ja: 夫は、私が看護師の仕事を続けることに批判的なんです。

examples.en: Viet told us the obvious lie that he found a girlfriend who’s a nurse.
examples.ja: ビエトは看護師の彼女が出来たという白々しい嘘をついた。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>expert</kanji> who <kanji>watches over</kanji> and <kanji>defend</kanji>s people at all hours is the <vocabulary>nurse</vocabulary>. That's what nurses do, 24/7. They have to check up on people, defend their health, and watch over them, making sure they're okay. What a tough job.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The lawyer Goodman faked an illness because he didn’t want to see Walt.
examples.ja: グッドマン弁護士はウォルトに会いたくなかったので仮病を使った。

examples.en: That attorney has finally shown his true colors.
examples.ja: あの弁護士、ついに尻尾を出しやがったぞ！

examples.en: After hearing the amount of the retainer fee, the lawyer changed his attitude.
examples.ja: 報酬の金額を聞いて、弁護士は態度を改めた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>samurai</kanji> who uses <kanji>speech</kanji> to <kanji>defend</kanji> people. This samurai does their battle in the court of law. This "samurai" is an <vocabulary>attorney</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>lawyer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's think about what we can do to conserve nature.
examples.ja: 自然を保護するために、何ができるか考えてみましょう。

examples.en: The police took the girl who was wandering by herself near Shinjuku Station into protective custody.
examples.ja: 警察は新宿駅近辺を一人で歩いていた少女を保護した。

examples.en: The bird pecking at insects over there is a species that is protected under international agreements.
examples.ja: あそこで虫をついばんでいる鳥は、国際間で保護することが取り決められた鳥です。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>preserve</kanji> and <kanji>defend</kanji> something is <vocabulary>to conserve</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary>. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I work as a teacher of jurisprudence.
examples.ja: 私は法律学の教師をしています。

examples.en: I don’t like that teacher because he is always flip-flopping on historical facts.
examples.ja: あの教師は歴史認識をころころ変えるからあまり好きじゃない。

examples.en: On the math teacher's desk, there was an answer sheet for the exam that tests understanding.
examples.ja: 数学教師の机には、理解力をテストする試験の解答が置いてありました。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>teach</kanji>ing <kanji>expert</kanji>/<kanji>teacher</kanji> is a <vocabulary>teacher</vocabulary>.

教師 is a relatively formal word for teachers. Unlike 先生, this word is specifically for people in the teaching profession and cannot be used as a name ender.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We've finally got some proof to expose that doctor!
examples.ja: ついにあの医師の尻尾をつかまえたぞ！

examples.en: Oh, that doctor is on TV a lot, right?
examples.ja: あっ、その医師って、テレビによく出てる方ですよね？

examples.en: This doctor appeared on TV twice, though just for short amounts of time.
examples.ja: ほんの短い時間だけでしたが、この医師は二度テレビに出たことがあるんです。

examples.en: According to the doctor, my grandfather's heartbeat became gradually weaker and weaker, then it finally stopped.
examples.ja: 医師によると、祖父の心拍はだんだん弱くなっていって、最後に停止したそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is someone who knows a lot about medicine. Those people are (I hope) generally <vocabulary>doctor</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Lawyers are experts in law.
examples.ja: 弁護士は、法律のエキスパートです。

examples.en: In Japan, there is no law against walking and drinking in the street.
examples.ja: 日本には、道を歩きながら飲酒をしてはいけないという法律は無い。

examples.en: If you can memorize every legal term within one month, I will pay you a million dollars.
examples.ja: もし一ヶ月の間に全法律用語を覚えることができたら、百万ドルお支払いしてもいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Though there's no law about two kanji with the same meaning producing the same meaning, a <kanji>law</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji> is probably a <vocabulary>law</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is the answer to "seven divided by two," three with a remainder of one?
examples.ja: 七割る二の答えって、三余り一であってる？

examples.en: I’m sorry, I broke the plate.
examples.ja: ごめんなさい、お皿を割ってしまいました。

examples.en: Koichi showed that he could break one hundred roofing tiles right in half with a karate chop.
examples.ja: コウイチは空手チョップで百枚の瓦を真っ二つに割ってみせた。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>divide</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to divide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to split something</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>to break something</vocabulary>, as in ワイングラスを割る (to break a wine glass). After all, you’re technically dividing the object into parts if you break it, right?
reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you'll use here. It's the わ one, though, making it わる.

examples.en: I think my husband is doing a great job in his role as a father.
examples.ja: 私の夫は父親としての役割をしっかり果たしてくれていると思います。

examples.en: The internet will play a more important role in future elections.
examples.ja: インターネットは今後の選挙においてより重要な役割を担っていくでしょう。

examples.en: It's more efficient to divide up the roles and get it done together.
examples.ja: 役割分担をしてみんなで片付ける方が効率がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Let's <kanji>divide</kanji> the <kanji>duty</kanji> up amongst various people. Each person will have their own <vocabulary>role</vocabulary> in completing this duty.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. See how we divide up the duty of learning kanji into radicals and kanji and vocab? Makes it nice, right? Each piece is its own 役割.

examples.en: When I write an article, I have someone check it for me when it is about ten percent complete.
examples.ja: 記事を書く時は、一割ほどできたところでだれかにチェックしてもらいます。

examples.en: The number of Christians in Japan doesn't even reach 10%.
examples.ja: 日本でのキリスト教信者の数は一割にもおよばない。

examples.en: "This blowfish is a bit too expensive. Could you give me a discount?" "I’ll give you a 10% discount."
examples.ja: 「この河豚、ちょっと高すぎますよ。まけてもらえませんか？」「一割引きにしてあげましょう。」

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>division</kanji> is <vocabulary>ten percent</vocabulary>. You'll just have to imagine this in terms of tens going by. Must be some old Japanese percentage system that carried over or something. Just remember that one wari is ten percent, two waris are twenty percent, and so on.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the same as what you learned with the kanji. You know much more than ten percent of this word's reading already.

examples.en: The ratio of people who attended was eighty percent.
examples.ja: 出席者の割合は80%だった。

examples.en: I think most of the people who use that term are elderly people.
examples.ja: その言葉を使ってる人の割合は、年配の人がほとんどだと思うよ。

examples.en: Please tell me the ratio of boys to girls among WaniKani users.
examples.ja: ワニカニユーザーの男女の割合を教えてください。

examples.en: I thought it was going to take longer, but it was over relatively quickly.
examples.ja: もっと長引くかと思ってたけど、割合早く終わったね。

examples.en: In Japan, noodles that contain one hundred percent buckwheat flour are called jūwari soba.
examples.ja: 日本では、蕎麦粉の割合が100%の蕎麦を十割り蕎麦と呼びます。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>divide</kanji> something into parts and <kanji>join</kanji> them back together, you are better able to evaluate the <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>percentage</vocabulary> of these parts in relation to the whole. Think of all these parts, neatly separated and then placed next to one another. It's only because you divided them that you get to see them this way.

割合 usually refers to the ratio of a certain part when compared to the whole, often expressed as a percentage. When used this way it's similar to 比率, but 割合 is more common in everyday language.

Note that 割合 can also be used as an adverb, where it means <vocabulary>comparatively</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

examples.en: In a trial it's necessary to judge as fairly as possible.
examples.ja: 裁判ではできるだけ公平に裁く必要があります。

examples.en: Surely his crime will be judged by the Supreme Court.
examples.ja: きっとアイツの罪は最高裁判所で裁かれるさ。

examples.en: It finally came out that the man is a murderer, but the statute of limitations has run out, so no one can legally try him.
examples.ja: 折角あの男が殺人犯だとが分かったのに、時効を迎えているせいで法的には誰もヤツを裁く事ができないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>judge</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to judge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you go <vocabulary>to judge</vocabulary> people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the <reading>sobber</reading> (さば). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.

examples.en: I'd like to avoid a trial, if possible.
examples.ja: できるだけ、裁判はしたくないんですよね。

examples.en: Do you know how much the cost of a trial would be?
examples.ja: 裁判の費用がいくらぐらいかかるか知っていますか？

examples.en: This piggy bank contains the eighty dollars I’ve saved from my allowance, but I guess it is not close to enough to file a lawsuit.
examples.ja: この貯金箱には小遣いからためた80ドルが入っているんだけど、裁判を起こすには到底足りないと思うんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You're going to get <kanji>judge</kanji>d times two. <kanji>Judge</kanji> and <kanji>judge</kanji> again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole <vocabulary>trial</vocabulary> here.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You hopefully learned this on'yomi for 判 with the word 評判, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

After your <reading>ban</reading> (ばん) on the WaniKani forums, you now face <vocabulary>trial</vocabulary> before none other than Judge Koichi. He's going to decide whether your ban will be lifted or not. Good luck, there's a lot at stake.

examples.en: I started reading Naoya Shiga’s novel, "At Cape Kinosaki" today.
examples.ja: 今日志賀直哉の小説『城の崎にて』を読み始めました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

In modern Japanese, this word is not commonly used as a standalone term. However, it is often found as part of proper nouns that refer to geographic locations that have a cape, as well as family names that are associated with capes.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The suspect ran off with his tail between his legs, but he was caught in Kawasaki.
examples.ja: 犯人は、尻尾をまいて逃げたが、川崎でつかまった。

examples.en: I heard that there is a disease affecting children called Kawasaki Disease, but what kind of disease is it?
examples.ja: 川崎病という子どもの病気があると聞きましたが、それはどんな病気ですか？

examples.en: I'd like to pay a proper visit to the graves in Kawasaki at least once.
examples.ja: 一度、川崎のお墓にきちんと挨拶に行きたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is one of those words that's easier to know if you jump to the reading first. Why? Because it's the name of a city. It's <vocabulary>Kawasaki</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, making it <reading>Kawasaki</reading>.

examples.en: My family name is Nagasaki, so everybody calls me Naga-chan.
examples.ja: 私の名字は長崎なので、みんなには長ちゃんって呼ばれています。

examples.en: I've never been to Kawasaki, but I've been to Nagasaki.
examples.ja: 川崎には行ったことがないですが、長崎になら行ったことがあります。

examples.en: I bought some Nagasaki sponge cake as a souvenir.
examples.ja: お土産に長崎カステラを買ったよー。

meaning_mnemonic: This word will be easier if you jump to the reading, since it's the name of a place, <vocabulary>Nagasaki</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The 長 is the kun'yomi reading, which comes from 長い. The 崎 part is the same reading that you learned with the kanji (though also kun'yomi). Combine those together and you have <reading>ながさき</reading>. Sound familiar? It should. This is the city of <vocabulary>Nagasaki</vocabulary>, one of the cities in which the A-bombs fell.

examples.en: What's the standard for judging whether it's a good or bad article?
examples.ja: 良い記事か悪い記事かの判断の基準は何ですか？

examples.en: We are going to talk about the establishment of safety standards at today's meeting.
examples.ja: 今日の会議では、安全基準の策定について話し合います。

examples.en: The quality of our product is far above industry standards.
examples.ja: 私達は、製品の品質において、業界基準を大きく上回っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>foundation</kanji> of your <kanji>standard</kanji> is where you place your <vocabulary>standard</vocabulary>. No more, no less. This foundation is where the standard is all based off of.

This word generally refers to a quantitative "standard" that’s a basis for evaluation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When they told me it was a foul, blood was rushing to my head, and I didn't immediately understand what was being said.
examples.ja: 反則だと言われた時は頭に血がのぼっていて、すぐに言われたことが理解できなかった。

examples.en: That player always fouls like that when he can't be seen.
examples.ja: あの選手は、ああやって、見えないところでいつも反則するんだよ。

examples.en: It’s a pretty cheeky move to use filters on dating app profile pictures. It’s almost like you’re a different person.
examples.ja: 出会い系アプリのプロフの写真にフィルター使うのは反則だよ。ほぼ別人じゃん。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji> is when you break the rules. It's when you do a <vocabulary>foul</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Hmm, is there a good way to teach a six-year-old about the law of gravity?
examples.ja: うーん、六才の子に、重力の法則を教えるいい方法ってありますか？

examples.en: That bacon was eaten by Mami according to the law of nature.
examples.ja: そのベーコンは、自然の法則によってマミに食べられた。

examples.en: If a rabbit jumps straight up in the cabin of a high speed train, according to the law of inertia, it will land in the same place.
examples.ja: もしウサギが高速で走っている電車の車内で真っすぐ上に飛び跳ねても、慣性の法則によって同じ場所に着地することになります。

meaning_mnemonic: It's both a <kanji>law</kanji> and a <kanji>rule</kanji>. This usually refers to something that is a <vocabulary>physical law</vocabulary>, but also can simply be a <vocabulary>law</vocabulary>, too. Anyways, lots of rules. Lots of laws. It's both, so the stronger one (law) takes precedence.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: To prepare for our old age, we had our house renovated to be wheelchair-accessible.
examples.ja: 老後に備えて、家をバリアフリーにしました。

examples.en: The Tofugu office was equipped with a telephone, but hardly anybody uses it.
examples.ja: トーフグのオフィスに電話が備え付けられましたが、ほとんどだれも使っていません。

examples.en: Brace yourself and prepare for your opponent’s attack!
examples.ja: 気持ちを引き締めて敵の攻撃に備えろ！

examples.en: I used to think days off were for preparing for work. I see now it's okay to use them to enjoy myself!
examples.ja: 休日って仕事に備えるためのものだと思ってました。自分が楽しむために使ってもいいんですね！

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>provide</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to provide</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have <vocabulary>to provide</vocabulary> your friends with their own <reading>sauna</reading> (そな) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.

examples.en: Are you ready?
examples.ja: 準備はいい？

examples.en: Good morning. If it's about breakfast, it's already prepared.
examples.ja: おはよう。朝ご飯の準備なら、もうできてるよ。

examples.en: I'm sorry, I gave in to the temptation to sleep in, and couldn't make it in time to prepare for the birthday party.
examples.ja: ごめん。ゆっくり寝たいっていう誘惑に負けちゃって、誕生日パーティーの準備、間に合わなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: When you follow standard procedure to provide what's needed, you make the perfect preparation! Both 準備 and 用意 mean "preparation," but the nuances are different. 準備 is about preparing in advance for an event or situation, often involving planning or setup. 用意 is about making sure specific items or resources are ready and available. For example, as part of the 準備 for a party, you might 用意 food and drinks for the guests. You could use 準備 for the food and drinks too — it would just emphasize that they're part of the overall event setup.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Isn't it the teacher's job to guide their students on the right path?
examples.ja: 生徒達を正しい道に導くのが教師の仕事だろ？

examples.en: The boxer taunted his opponent with words, causing the opponent to lose by foul play.
examples.ja: あのボクサーは、言葉で相手をイライラさせて、対戦相手を反則負けに導いた。

examples.en: I think you misunderstand my father. He’s not the type of person who would lead someone into committing a heinous crime.
examples.ja: あなたは父のことを誤解していると思います。彼は決して誰かを凶悪犯罪へと導くような人ではありません。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lead</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lead</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the 道 in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's みち. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Let's say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a <reading>道 Bee</reading> (みちび)!

examples.en: I don't know if this is the right way to give guidance.
examples.ja: これが正しい指導の仕方かは分からない。

examples.en: I just gave guidance on the harsh realities of life.
examples.ja: 人生のきびしい現実を指導してやっただけです。

examples.en: She is a bit careless, but she’s a very smart leader.
examples.ja: 彼女は不注意ですが、とても頭のいい指導者です。

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <kanji>finger</kanji> and <kanji>lead</kanji> with it. Just point at things. Tell people where they need to go, what they need to do, all with your finger leading them. This is <vocabulary>guidance</vocabulary> you are providing.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

examples.en: Who scratched the tree trunk?!
examples.ja: 誰だ、幹にキズを付けたのは。

examples.en: When I rubbed the tree trunk, I felt as if I’d touched the loneliness of the tree.
examples.ja: その木の幹をなでた時、木のさびしさにふれた気がしたんです。

examples.en: You should remove the ivy winding around the tree trunk.
examples.ja: 木の幹に絡まっているツタを取り除いた方がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

When you cut the tree down to produce a <vocabulary>tree trunk</vocabulary>, out jumps <reading>Mickey</reading> Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.

examples.en: I'm going to take a bullet train to Okayama tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は新幹線で岡山に行きます。

examples.en: On the Shinkansen I was given these hollow compliments by the person sitting next to me.
examples.ja: 新幹線で、となりの席の人に白々しいお世辞を言われました。

examples.en: I could hear nothing, save for the rolling thunder of a Shinkansen passing by.
examples.ja: 走りすぎる新幹線の鈍い轟を除いては物音一つ聞こえなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. Technically this is the "New Tree Trunk Line" but you wouldn't realize this is the Japanese <vocabulary>bullet train</vocabulary> aka <vocabulary>Shinkansen</vocabulary> from that, would you? Maybe going to the reading will help you after all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Read this to be able to remember the meaning, too, which is <vocabulary>Shinkansen</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I was taught how to stretch a canvas over a frame.
examples.ja: キャンバスをフレームに張る方法を教わりました。

examples.en: Who put up the volleyball net?
examples.ja: バレーボールのネットを張ったのは誰ですか？

examples.en: I'd like to stretch the tent more tightly. Could you help me?
examples.ja: テントをもうちょっとピンと張りたいんですが、手伝ってくれませんか？

examples.en: I went jogging for the first time in a while, so my legs are swollen and tense.
examples.ja: 久々にジョギングしたから、足がパンパンに張ってる。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stretch</kanji>, and the verb version means <vocabulary>to stretch over something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be taut</vocabulary>, not to be confused with the type of stretching you do after a workout.

This word is both transitive and intransitive. When it follows を, it emphasizes the physical act of extending something over an area, like stretching a canvas over a frame, unfurling a sail on a ship, or roping off a crime scene. When following が, it expresses the resulting state of having been stretched or spread, like a bloated stomach, a swollen muscle, or a spider web.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Imagine yourself trying <vocabulary>to stretch</vocabulary> your favorite toy figurine, seeing just how far you can stretch it. With every stretch, you start laughing uncontrollably, <reading>HA</reading> (は) HA HA HA HA HA. Seems a bit cruel. Are you okay?

examples.en: Chris has a bit of a wild side, but he’s very kind despite his appearance.
examples.ja: クリスはちょっとヤンチャだけど、ああ見えてすごく優しいんだよ。

examples.en: My husband changes his demeanor in public and pretends to be nice.
examples.ja: 夫は人前では態度が変わって、優しいふりをするんです。

examples.en: My brother is still very young, so he hasn't yet fully grasped the passing of his sweet mother.
examples.ja: 弟はまだ幼いので、優しい母の死をまだ理解できずにいます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>gentle</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> (but also <vocabulary>kind</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>warm hearted</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do people who are <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>kind</vocabulary> say when someone asks of them a favor? Always "<reading>yessir</reading>" (やさ). Always, always "yessir"!

examples.en: That actor is famous for his terrible attitude toward his fans.
examples.ja: あの男優、ファンに対する態度がひどいので有名だよ。

examples.en: Oh, that's the actor who became famous for his second movie, right?
examples.ja: あ、それって、二作目の映画で有名になった男優だよね。

examples.en: From the time he was a newcomer, that actor had expressed his sincere desire to win the Best Actor award.
examples.ja: その俳優は新人の時から、「主演男優賞を狙いたい」と真面目に語っていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>man</kanji> who is <kanji>superior</kanji> to us is an <vocabulary>actor</vocabulary>, or more specifically a <vocabulary>male actor</vocabulary>.

Just a word of warning: over the years this word has taken on the connotation of "adult film actor" so most people would use 俳優 for "actor" now. You'll be learning that word very soon!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is unacceptable for young people to shamelessly sit in priority seating for the elderly.
examples.ja: 若い人がお年寄優先座席に堂々と座っているのはいただけない。

examples.en: I think our company should prioritize the development of new flavors of bacon.
examples.ja: うちの会社は、新しいベーコンのフレーバーの開発を優先するべきだと思うんだよね。

examples.en: By prioritizing tasks, we are striving to work more efficiently.
examples.ja: 優先事項を決めて、効率良く仕事をするように努めています。

meaning_mnemonic: It was <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>previous</kanji>ly, so we need to go back there. That, amongst all the other things, is our highest <vocabulary>priority</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Although the Giants got their butts kicked big time last year, they won the championship this year.
examples.ja: ジャイアンツは去年はボロ負けだったが、今年はリーグ優勝を果たした。

examples.en: If you win first place, you can get a Persian carpet.
examples.ja: 優勝したら、ペルシャじゅうたんがもらえるんだ。

examples.en: Koichi led Tofugu to its first championship.
examples.ja: コウイチがトーフグを初優勝に導きました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>superior</kanji> person <kanji>win</kanji>s. They will win the <vocabulary>championship</vocabulary> and be able to claim <vocabulary>victory</vocabulary> over all others.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am visiting the Yamadas' house today.
examples.ja: 今日は山田宅におじゃましてます。

meaning_mnemonic: Just like its kanji, this word means <vocabulary>house</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>home</vocabulary>. By extension, it also sometimes means <vocabulary>household</vocabulary>. It can go after someone’s name to say whose house it is, as in 山田宅 (Yamada’s house), and after words that give more information about the house, such as 女性宅 (women’s homes).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go home now.

examples.en: I heard a voice calling for help from the bathroom in my house.
examples.ja: 自宅のトイレから、助けを呼ぶ声が聞こえてきたんです。

examples.en: This week, my girlfriend invited me to her home.
examples.ja: 今週、彼女に自宅に招待されたんだ。

examples.en: Bill always throws extravagant parties at his house.
examples.ja: ビルはいつも自宅で贅沢なパーティーを開いている。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>home</kanji> is your own home. It's <vocabulary>one's home</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Houses in this area were unharmed even during that great earthquake.
examples.ja: この地域の住宅は、あの大地震のときも大丈夫だったんです。

examples.en: Even in recent years, many Japanese houses have Japanese-style rooms.
examples.ja: 近年でも、日本の住宅の多くには和室があります。

examples.en: The number of dwellings with nuclear shelters has increased in preparation for war.
examples.ja: 戦争に備えて、核シェルターを備え付けている住宅が増えています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>dwell</kanji> in a <kanji>house</kanji>, that house is your <vocabulary>dwelling</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Traveling first class is too extravagant.
examples.ja: ファーストクラスでの旅行なんて、贅沢すぎるよ。

examples.en: In the winter, Koichi comes to the office with a luxurious fugu skin coat.
examples.ja: 冬になると、コウイチは贅沢なフグ皮のコートを着て出社する。

examples.en: I don't want to do anything extravagant for my birthday. If I can just read a good book, I'm happy.
examples.ja: 誕生日だからって贅沢な事は何もしたくないわ。良い本が読めればそれでいいの。

meaning_mnemonic: You live in the most <kanji>extravagant</kanji> of <kanji>swamp</kanji>s, which means you’re completely surrounded by <vocabulary>luxury</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>extravagant</vocabulary> things.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The law is scheduled to take effect on the fifth of next month.
examples.ja: その法律は来月五日に施行される予定です。

examples.en: Do you remember who is responsible for the enforcement of this law?
examples.ja: この法律の施行の責任を誰が負っていたのか覚えていますか？

examples.en: The implementation of that law hasn’t been finalized yet.
examples.ja: まだその法律の施行が確定したわけではない。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>carry out</kanji> something and <kanji>go</kanji>, the result is still <vocabulary>enforcement</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>carrying out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>implementation</vocabulary> of whatever it is. There’s no point hanging around after you’ve enforced something! So you always carry out and go.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You might sometimes see せこう as an alternative reading, but しこう is the more common version.

examples.en: If you wait here, I'm sure that tabby cat will show up again.
examples.ja: ここで待っていれば、きっとまたあのトラ猫が現れるよ。

examples.en: I'm glad someone has come along who understands my dreams without laughing at them.
examples.ja: 私の夢を笑わずに理解してくれる人が現れて、うれしいです。

examples.en: Even when he oversleeps, he always shows up to the office playing dumb, with a look on his face that says "What, late? Not me."
examples.ja: アイツはいつも、寝坊しても、遅刻なんてしてませんという顔をして白々しくオフィスに現れる。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>appear</kanji>, so this word means <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to emerge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Some kind of paranormal entity starts <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary> in front of you. "You… <reading>are a wa</reading>lrus (あらわ)!" you scream, terrified. Yes, it seems a ghostly walrus has appeared before you. It has come from beyond the grave to warn you that the Crabigator will get you if you don't do your reviews!

examples.en: Every Tofugu article has unique and interesting figures of speech.
examples.ja: トーフグの記事は、どれも表現がユニークでおもしろい。

examples.en: When I was able to understand artistic expressions that I hadn’t understood before, words can’t express how happy I was.
examples.ja: 以前は理解できなかった芸術表現が理解できるようになった時、言葉では表現できないほどうれしかった。

examples.en: Last night in my dream, our baby told me that it’s time for her baby teeth to come out and she can’t express in words how itchy they are.
examples.ja: 昨夜の夢で、私たちの赤ちゃんに「乳歯が抜けそうだった時、言葉では表現できないほど痒かった」って言われたの。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>express</kanji> something that's of the <kanji>present time</kanji>, you are saying something that only people of the current time understand. These are <vocabulary>expression</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>figure of speech</vocabulary>. You say these things during the present time, not the future, not the past, the present time. Otherwise nobody would understand.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is this a dream or real?
examples.ja: これは夢か、現実か？

examples.en: It's important to understand the reality first.
examples.ja: まずは、現実を正しく理解することが大切です。

examples.en: "For God’s sake, face reality! This isn’t cake, it’s poop!"
examples.ja: 「頼むから、現実を見てくれよ！これはケーキじゃなくてウンチなんだ！」

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>present</kanji> is the <kanji>truth</kanji>. It is what's going on right now. It is <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I hope live streaming can convey how fun the atmosphere is here right now.
examples.ja: ライブストリーミングで、現場の楽しい空気感が伝わればいいなと思っています。

examples.en: If you want to change this rule, please get approval from the on-site workers first.
examples.ja: このルールを変えたければ、まず現場の了解を取ってください。

examples.en: Let's hope that what actually happened at the scene of the crime will come to light soon.
examples.ja: あの犯罪現場で実際に何が起きたのかがすぐに明るみに出ることを期待しよう。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>present</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is the <vocabulary>on-site location</vocabulary>! And you're on the <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary> to check out what's currently going on.

現場 refers to an on-site location where something is happening or has happened. It can refer to a crime scene, an accident site, or a filming location. It may also refer to a construction site or a factory, as these are <vocabulary>workplace</vocabulary>s where more hands-on work or operations take place.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is a combination of the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

At this crime <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary>, a "<reading>baa</reading>" (ば) was apparently heard by witnesses. This can only mean one thing: that infamous arch-criminal, the Lamb-Chopper, has struck again! Baa!

examples.en: Ahhh, the milk's spilled!
examples.ja: あーっ牛乳こぼれてるよー！

examples.en: Good morning. Here’s your milk.
examples.ja: おはよう。はい、牛乳よ。

examples.en: There's nothing better than having some good milk to drink while watching the sunrise.
examples.ja: 朝日を見ながら飲む美味しい牛乳に勝るものはないね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Cow</kanji> <kanji>milk</kanji> is <vocabulary>cow's milk</vocabulary>, though most people just call cow's milk <vocabulary>milk</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That man dancing over there with chikuwa on each of his nipples is my boss.
examples.ja: あそこで乳首にチクワを付けてダンスしてる人が私の上司です。

examples.en: My nipples are covered with scabs because the baby bites them.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんにかまれて、乳首がカサブタだらけになってるんです。

examples.en: When I saw all the blood spurting out of your nipples, I couldn't help but panic!
examples.ja: あんたの乳首から血がふき出しているのを見て、思わずパニクッちゃったよ！

examples.en: I've sterilized the feeding bottle nipples with boiling water.
examples.ja: 哺乳瓶の乳首、熱湯消毒しておいたよ！

meaning_mnemonic: What is a <kanji>milk</kanji> <kanji>neck</kanji>? Think about where milk comes from. Now, think of what looks like a little neck on the thing that milk comes from. What is that thing? It's a <vocabulary>nipple</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this one is an exception, you already know that 首 is read as くび, but 乳 in this case is read as ち. Here's a mnemonic to help you.

You come across a <vocabulary>nipple</vocabulary> and decide to milk it so that you can make some <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). That's a little bit strange. You should probably find out who this nipple belongs to and ask them if you can do that first.

examples.en: Could you call a taxi for me?
examples.ja: タクシーを呼んでもらえますか？

examples.en: A stranger suddenly called out my name at the airport.
examples.ja: 空港で、見知らぬ人に名前を大声で呼ばれた。

examples.en: He saved your life so you should invite him to your birthday party.
examples.ja: 彼はあなたの命の恩人なんだから、誕生日会に呼んだ方がいいわよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>call</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to call</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to call out</vocabulary>. As in "HEY, YOU!"
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself  calling out to someone: "<reading>YO</reading> (よ)! You!"

examples.en: Eating and drinking are prohibited in this castle.
examples.ja: この城の中では、飲食は禁止です。

examples.en: The castles that still remain have all become famous sightseeing spots.
examples.ja: 今でも残っているお城は、全て観光名所になっています。

examples.en: If I won the lottery, I would build my own castle in the back yard.
examples.ja: もし宝くじが当たったら、裏庭に自分のお城を建てるね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: That actor has a real attitude problem.
examples.ja: あの俳優は、態度に問題がある。

examples.en: That actress is always fawning over big actors, so other actresses don't like her.
examples.ja: その女優は、いつも大物俳優に尻尾をふっているため、他の女優から嫌われている。

examples.en: My boyfriend is the actor performing the part of the horse in this play.
examples.ja: 私の恋人は、この芝居で馬の役を演じている俳優よ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>haiku</kanji> requires someone really famous and well known to read it... it's just on that level. Who is super well known and who deserves to read this superior haiku? A great <vocabulary>actor</vocabulary>, perhaps?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: A Japanese person wouldn't let these haiku mistakes slide.
examples.ja: 日本人だったら、この俳句のミスは放っておかないよね。

examples.en: I often write haiku while riding my bike.
examples.ja: 私はよく自転車に乗りながら俳句を作ります。

examples.en: The haiku he composed today was so romantic, wasn’t it?
examples.ja: 彼が今日詠んだ俳句、すごくロマンチックだったわよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>haiku</kanji> <kanji>paragraph</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>haiku</vocabulary>. Haikus are little haiku paragraphs.

You will learn kanji
The Crabigator watches
He feeds on reviews
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Students who excel in a particular field can enter this university through a different route.
examples.ja: この大学には、一芸に秀でる学生は別ルートで入学することができる。

examples.en: Satomi excels at expressing her thoughts.
examples.ja: サトミは、自分の考えを表現することに秀でている。

examples.en: The only thing I excel at is picking my nose. In fact, I have never made my nose bleed.
examples.ja: 私は鼻くそをほじくることだけには秀でています。実際、鼻血を出すはめになったこともありません。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>excel</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

"<reading>He-e</reading> (ひい) is going <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary>," you stutter. "He-e is!"

examples.en: Leo is much more capable than I am.
examples.ja: レオは僕なんかよりずっと優秀です。

examples.en: Aya got an award for excellence in an art contest.
examples.ja: アヤは、絵画コンクールで優秀賞をもらいました。

examples.en: Superior system administrators prepare for any possibility of hacking.
examples.ja: 優秀なシステム管理者は、ハッキングによるいかなる攻撃の可能性にも備えます。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that's <kanji>superior</kanji> will <kanji>excel</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>superior</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>excellent</vocabulary> in every way.

This word is typically used to describe someone's superiority or excellence, often in comparison to others.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have to finish this article about economics by the end of this month.
examples.ja: この経済学についての記事を、今月末までにあげないといけないんです。

examples.en: He's a genius who finished writing his graduation thesis on economics in only one day.
examples.ja: ヤツは、この経済学についての卒論をたった一日で書き上げた天才です。

examples.en: I don't know the first thing about economics, so I decided to go to school.
examples.ja: 経済学の「け」の字も知らないので、学校に行くことにしたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 経済 is economics, right? Well, add <kanji>study</kanji> to that and you have the study of economics, aka <vocabulary>economics</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

examples.en: If I were to give examples, it would be endless.
examples.ja: 例を挙げるとキリがないですよ。

examples.en: When I call your name, please raise your hand.
examples.ja: 名前を呼んだら、手を挙げてください。

examples.en: I held my wedding ceremony in city hall, and I’m not ashamed of that.
examples.ja: 私は結婚式を市役所で挙げましたが、そのことを恥ずかしいとは思っていません。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>raise</kanji>, and this verb is when you do that to something. It's transitive. So this means <vocabulary>to raise something</vocabulary>. It actually has a pretty wide meaning, and can also mean "raise" in the sense of <vocabulary>to cite something</vocabulary>, like an example. It can even mean <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary>, like an event.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 挙がる, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.

examples.en: My boyfriend always gives me a hard candy after criticizing me.
examples.ja: 私の彼は、私を批判すると、いつも後でアメをくれる。

examples.en: Everyone said the same thing and criticized the man.
examples.ja: みんなは口をそろえて男のことを批判した。

examples.en: You're always finding fault with other people, aren't you?
examples.ja: お前って、他人の批判してばっかりだよな。

meaning_mnemonic: 批判 is <kanji>criticism</kanji> so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know 批判, as well.

examples.en: We really should increase the number of writers who have some literary talent.
examples.ja: もっと文才のあるライターを増やすべきだ。

examples.en: We want to increase the number of Tofugu fans. What do you think we should do?
examples.ja: トーフグのファンをもっと増やしたいんだけど、どうしたらいいかな？

examples.en: I save all my homework for the weekend so I can spend more time with my family on weekdays.
examples.ja: 平日に家族と過ごす時間を増やすために、宿題は全部週末にやることにしてるんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 増える is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means <vocabulary>to increase something</vocabulary>. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (やす) to increasing something, and did it yourself.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same like 増える. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.

examples.en: This means that there's no longer any way to escape.
examples.ja: これでもう逃げ道は断たれてしまった。

examples.en: I know that I should cut out alcohol and cigarettes. My doctor also told me to cut them out, but there’s no way I could do so right away.
examples.ja: お酒とタバコを断つべきだってのは、自分でも分かってます。医者にも断つように言われたんですが、すぐには無理ですよ。

examples.en: At that time, I said goodbye with a gut-wrenching feeling.
examples.ja: あの時は、はらわたを断つ思いで別れを告げたんだ。

examples.en: The goal of feminism is to sever the chains that bind women. It is not about forcing women to "lose their femininity," but about resisting the oppression of "this is how women are supposed to be.”
examples.ja: フェミニズムの目的は、女性を縛る鎖を断つことです。「女性らしさを失う」ことを押し付けるのではなく、「女性はこうあるべきだ」という抑圧への抵抗なんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut off</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>.

This is often used metaphorically to describe cutting off things that tie us down mentally or societally. This includes ending bad habits, so it also means <vocabulary>to quit doing something</vocabulary>.

Don't confuse this with 断る which means "to refuse." You know this is to cut off because of the つ, which hints that you have had <reading>two</reading> (つ) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off.
reading_mnemonic: URGH! The reading isn't even the same as 断る, how frustrating. <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> is read as たつ. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater <reading>tots</reading> (たつ). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.

examples.en: At this sports facility you can swim, skate, and play tennis.
examples.ja: このスポーツ施設では、スイミングやスケート、テニスなどができます。

examples.en: There are many museums and other cultural facilities in this town.
examples.ja: この町には美術館などの文化施設がたくさんあります。

examples.en: In a medical facility, doctors and nurses examine and care for patients.
examples.ja: 医療施設では、医者や看護師が患者さんを診察したり看護したりします。

examples.en: I’d like to quit my job at the children’s home because it’s too hard, but, at the same time, I don’t want to go burning any bridges.
examples.ja: 児童養護施設の仕事がきついので辞めたいんですが、一方で今まで築き上げてきた関係も壊したくはないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>carry out</kanji> the task and <kanji>establish</kanji> the <vocabulary>institution</vocabulary>. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That time came suddenly.
examples.ja: その時は、突然やって来ました。

examples.en: Due to a sudden heavy rain, I got completely soaked.
examples.ja: 突然の大雨で、ビショビショになってしまった。

examples.en: It was so sudden that I did not know what was what.
examples.ja: 突然のことだったので、何が何だか分かりませんでした。

examples.en: Suddenly the ghost of a cat showed up in my kitchen and started singing the mew-mew song.
examples.ja: 突然、猫のお化けが台所に現れて、「ニャーニャーソング」を歌い始めたんだ。

examples.en: Suddenly, hundreds of red-haired people came out of the hospital. When I spoke to one of them, I was told there had been a large medical experiment involving red-haired individuals.
examples.ja: 病院から突然、何百人もの赤毛の人々が出てきました。その中の一人に話しかけると、赤毛の人に対する大きな医学実験があったと言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: When something happens with a <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji>, it happens... <vocabulary>suddenly</vocabulary>.
