reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Be careful when getting off the bus.
examples.ja: バスから降りるときは、気をつけてください。

examples.en: Before getting out of the taxi, I checked to make sure I hadn't left anything behind.
examples.ja: タクシーを降りる前に、忘れ物がないか確認しました。

examples.en: We're getting off at the next station, so please get ready.
examples.ja: 次の駅で降りるので、準備してください。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>descend</kanji>, but this verb vocab word is <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary>, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the <reading>real</reading> (りる) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train.

Figuratively, this word also means <vocabulary>to step down</vocabulary>, as in "to give up" or "to resign” from something. For example, you can say ニュース番組を降りる (to step down from a news program) or ゲームを降りる (to drop out of a game).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary> at <reading>O</reading>-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just <reading>O</reading>-Station (お).

examples.en: The changing rooms are over there.
examples.ja: 更衣室はあそこです。

examples.en: There are no changing rooms in this gym.
examples.ja: このジムには更衣室はありません。

examples.en: I'm in the locker room looking for her locker now.
examples.ja: 今更衣室であの女のロッカーを探しているところよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>renew</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>changing room</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>locker room</vocabulary>.

更衣室 is a room where people change their clothes, commonly found in places like gyms, swimming pools, schools, or workplaces.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My father built this shelf by himself.
examples.ja: この棚は、父が自分で作ったんです。

examples.en: There were lots of delicious-looking sweets lined up on the convenience store shelves.
examples.ja: コンビニの棚には、おいしそうなお菓子がたくさんならんでいた。

examples.en: The cups are on the shelf over there.
examples.ja: コップはあそこの棚にあります。

examples.en: Fugu calls me fat. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. (Literally: to talk about it while putting himself up on the shelf)
examples.ja: フグが僕のことをデブって呼ぶんだよね。自分のことを棚に上げてよく言うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Oh, it's not on the bookshelf?
examples.ja: あれ、本棚にない？

examples.en: I'm planning to organize the bookshelf today.
examples.ja: 今日は本棚を整理するつもりです。

examples.en: My father's bookshelves were filled with novels.
examples.ja: 父の本棚にはたくさんの小説がならんでいた。

examples.en: I found a book in his bookcase about how to eat and run.
examples.ja: 彼の本棚に、食い逃げの仕方について書かれた本を見つけたんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>book</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bookcase</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bookshelf</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: I installed a new cabinet.
examples.ja: 新しい戸棚をつけたんです。

examples.en: If you're looking for spoons and forks, they're in the drawer in the cabinet there.
examples.ja: スプーンやフォークなら、そこの戸棚の引き出しに入ってるよ。

examples.en: When I opened the cabinet, I found many spices and seasonings.
examples.ja: 戸棚を開くと、たくさんのスパイスや調味料がならんでいた。

examples.en: I left the AA batteries I bought today on top of the cupboard.
examples.ja: 今日買った単三電池は戸棚の上に置いておいたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>door</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a shelf with a door on it. What kinds of shelves do you know of that have doors on them? How about <vocabulary>cabinet</vocabulary>s? Or maybe <vocabulary>cupboard</vocabulary>s?
reading_mnemonic: These readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Just keep in mind that 棚 gets rendaku'd to だな.

examples.en: The instant I saw purple light shining through the darkness, I thought, "Mom."
examples.ja: 暗闇の中でキラキラ光る紫色の光を見た瞬間、「母だ」と思ったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading of 紫 when you learned the kanji, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: She always wears a purple colored vest over her school uniform.
examples.ja: 彼女はいつも制服の上に紫色のベストを着ている。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>purple</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is <vocabulary>purple</vocabulary>. Simple as that!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji.

examples.en: I aspire to be an actor who can convey emotions through facial expressions.
examples.ja: 表情で演技ができる役者を目指しています。

examples.en: Fugu is studying acting at university.
examples.ja: フグは大学で演技の勉強をしています。

examples.en: That actress’s acting ability is magnificent.
examples.ja: あの女優の演技力は素晴らしい。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>performance</kanji> <kanji>skill</kanji> allows you to be great at <vocabulary>acting</vocabulary> and doing awesome <vocabulary>performance</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Enzuru" is a more formal expression for "enjiru."
examples.ja: 「演ずる」は「演じる」の、よりフォーマルな表現です。

examples.en: You seem to not understand how difficult it is to play the role of a dog that expresses joy with its tail.
examples.ja: 尻尾で喜びを示す犬の役を演ずるのがどんなに大変なことか、あなたは分かってらっしゃらないようですね。

examples.en: I am excited to announce that I have been chosen to play the pivotal role of the United States President in our next YouTube video.
examples.ja: この度、私は、次のYoutubeビデオで、アメリカ大統領という大役を演ずることになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: If 演 is <kanji>performance</kanji> then the verb version of this would be <vocabulary>to perform</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading looks weird, but it's actually just the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The performance is next week! Let's do our best, everyone!
examples.ja: 演芸会は来週ですよ！みなさん、がんばりましょう！

examples.en: At Tofugu, the one who excels most as an entertainer is Michael.
examples.ja: トーフグで一番演芸に秀でているのはマイケルだ。

examples.en: I would like to join the performing arts club. Do you know how I can do that?
examples.ja: 演芸部に入部したいんですが、どうすればいいかご存知ですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
When you turn <kanji>acting</kanji> into <kanji>art</kanji> you get the <vocabulary>performing arts</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>popular entertainment</vocabulary>! Lights, action! Welcome to Broadway!

This word is more traditional and isn't used very much these days.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can you tell me the time of the Lion King performance?
examples.ja: ライオンキングの上演時間を教えて下さい。

examples.en: In Japanese cinemas, Hollywood movies are the ones shown most often.
examples.ja: 日本の映画館ではハリウッド映画が一番多く上演されています。

examples.en: What time will the kabuki performance start?
examples.ja: 歌舞伎の上演は何時からですか。

meaning_mnemonic:
What's <kanji>above</kanji> the stage and involves <kanji>acting</kanji>? A <vocabulary>performance</vocabulary>!

This word does not refer to an actor's acting on stage. Instead, it usually refers to a theatrical or musical presentation in its entirety, so it's used in contexts relating to the act of staging an artistic or dramatic production, or features of the production itself, like its start time or running time (as in 上演時間).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How can you remember such a long speech?
examples.ja: こんな長い台詞、よく覚えられるわね。

examples.en: The lines sound kind of phony, don't they?
examples.ja: なんかウソっぽい台詞だね。

examples.en: I was the one who came up with that actor's line, "I don't like your attitude!"
examples.ja: あの男優の「お前の態度が気に入らないんだ！」っていう台詞は、オレが考えたんだぜ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>machine</kanji> that can quickly generate a <kanji>part of speech</kanji> is handy for remembering <vocabulary>one's lines</vocabulary> on stage. If you forget your <vocabulary>line</vocabulary>, just activate the machine, and it will give you a helpful prompt: "Adjective! Adjective!"

台詞 usually means a line or speech in a play, movie, or drama — something a character says out loud. But it's also used in everyday talk when someone makes a <vocabulary>remark</vocabulary> that's clever, dramatic, or memorable, almost like quoting a line.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

One can also use the machine to print out <vocabulary>one's lines</vocabulary> as text, but it only prints in <reading>serif</reading> (せりふ) font. Sorry, Comic Sans folks — you'll have to wait for next year's model.

examples.en: Does anyone know who this woman is?
examples.ja: このお方をどなたと心得るか。

examples.en: I’m well aware of the matter.
examples.ja: その件についてはよく心得ております。

examples.en: Captain Cook knows how to use Cookpad very well.
examples.ja: クック船長はクックパッドの使い方をよく心得ている。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 心得 means "knowledge"? Well the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>. (You know it deep in your heart.)
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In Canada, ten story apartment buildings are being covered in snow.
examples.ja: カナダでは、十階建てのアパートが雪で埋まる。

examples.en: My schedule is packed with appointments, so I don't have any time to rest.
examples.ja: スケジュールが予定で埋まっていて、休む時間がないんです。

examples.en: The seats at the venue filled up quickly.
examples.ja: 会場の席は、すぐに埋まってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how you learned that 埋める means "to bury?" Well this is something that is being buried, maybe even you! Either way, you're not the one doing the burying. It means <vocabulary>to be buried</vocabulary>.

埋まる can also mean to be filled, like a pond being completely filled by dirt from a landslide or seats being filled at an event.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: My older brother doesn't have a social life, but he doesn't mind much because of his optimism.
examples.ja: 兄は人付き合いがありませんが、楽天主義だから自分ではあまり気にしていません。

examples.en: I don't think anyone is more optimistic than he is.
examples.ja: あいつほど楽天主義だなあと思うやつはいない。

examples.en: Fugu is as optimistic as people say he is.
examples.ja: フグは評判通りの楽天主義者だね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 主義 is "-ism." If you add that to being <kanji>comfort</kanji>able like you're in <kanji>heaven</kanji> then you have lots of <vocabulary>optimism</vocabulary>. You're sure you'll be okay in any situation!

This is a noun in Japanese but, depending on the context, it's often translated into English as an adjective.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I got a lot of money this month.
examples.ja: 今月は沢山の金を手に入れた。

examples.en: I’ll make a lot of money next month, so we won't have to drink whiskey diluted with so much water.
examples.ja: 来月は大金が手に入るから、こんなに沢山の水で割ったウィスキーを飲まなくて済む。

examples.en: Since actually becoming a parent, whenever I see someone with a lot of kids, I think "Wow" and just feel admiration for them.
examples.ja: 実際に親になってからは、沢山の子を育てている人を見ると、すごいなぁとただただ感心します。

examples.en: Koichi possesses many of the qualities of a good leader.
examples.ja: コウイチは、優れた指導者に必要な要件を沢山備えています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Swamp</kanji>s and <kanji>mountain</kanji>s happen <vocabulary>a lot</vocabulary> in Japan. That's why we use this to mean <vocabulary>many</vocabulary>! Because there are many of them!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word is usually written in kana though, so keep that in mind when you're writing it to use kana and not these kanji!

examples.en: Didn’t you actually say that a while ago?
examples.ja: 現にさっきそう言ったじゃありませんか。

examples.en: Some people were actually killed. How can you say such a thing?
examples.ja: 現に人が死んでるっていうのに、よくそんなことが言えますね。

examples.en: There are actually people suffering from starvation at this very moment, you know.
examples.ja: 現にこの瞬間にも飢餓で苦しんでいる人がいるんですよ？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>present time</kanji> is the time you're <vocabulary>actually</vocabulary> in. You aren't <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> in any other time, because that's not how time works!
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Mom, I got a 100 points on the division test!
examples.ja: ママ、割り算のテストで100点取ったよ！

examples.en: For some reason, I am better at division than addition.
examples.ja: なぜか割り算は足し算より得意なんです。

examples.en: I got this simple division problem wrong.
examples.ja: こんな簡単な割り算の問題を間違えちゃったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Divide</kanji> and <kanji>calculate</kanji>? Why, that's just <vocabulary>division</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for 割 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

examples.en: I'm jealous of people who can speak Japanese fluently.
examples.ja: 日本語がペラペラと話せる人が羨ましい。

examples.en: I'm envious of you for being successful in business and looking good in sunglasses.
examples.ja: ビジネスで成功した上に、サングラスが似合うなんて、私はあなたが羨ましいですよ。

examples.en: If I told my little sister that I got a boyfriend I think she would be jealous.
examples.ja: 私に彼氏ができたって言ったら、妹が羨ましがると思うの。

examples.en: I saw my classmate's travel photos on Instagram and felt envious.
examples.ja: インスタでクラスメートが旅行に行った写真を見て、羨ましく思った。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with hiragana that ends in an い, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>envy</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>envious</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 羨む, but here's a reminder just in case:

Those <reading>ura</reading>nium <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (うらや) are making you more <vocabulary>envious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>jealous</vocabulary> by the day. They're the new Yankees team that was manufactured in a lab and fed uranium. Their skills are unparalleled because of their metallic strength. Go ahead and feel envious, they'll definitely be #1 this year.

examples.en: Did the one hundred million yen fit inside the suitcase?
examples.ja: 一億円、そのスーツケースに収まった？

examples.en: It looks like we'll somehow manage to stay within the budget.
examples.ja: なんとか予算内に収まりそうです。

examples.en: After eating the ice cream, my emotions started to settle down.
examples.ja: アイスを食べたら、感情が収まってきたんだよね。

examples.en: I wanted to eat all five large pizzas, but they couldn't be finished within the all-you-can-eat time limit.
examples.ja: 大きいピザを五枚食べ切りたかったが、食べ放題の時間内に収まらなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

If you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something, you'll want it <vocabulary>to fit inside</vocabulary> your bag. Otherwise how can you take it home? When talking about problems or emotions, this verb can also mean <vocabulary>to settle down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be finished</vocabulary> like a dispute settling down or someone’s anger calming down.

Like most verbs with まる as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something fit inside, or settle down.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don't fit inside your bed anymore. I guess you've grown? Better get out the trusty <reading>o</reading>ld <reading>saw</reading>s (おさ) and chop off your footboard.

examples.en: A new character will be added soon!
examples.ja: もうすぐ新しいキャラクターが加わるよ！

examples.en: When a little extra effort is put in, it draws out the depth of flavor in the dish.
examples.ja: ひと手間が加わると、料理の味に深みが出ます。

examples.en: The cost of advertising will be added to the ten million yen for the ingredients.
examples.ja: 材料の一千万円に、さらに広告のコストが加わる。

examples.en: When this paint is added to this, the color changes.
examples.ja: これにこの塗料が加わると、色が変わるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 加 means <kanji>add</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to be added to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to join in</vocabulary>.

It is an intransitive verb, like most verbs ending in わる. That means that it happens by itself, or at least the cause of the adding is not you. Something gets added to something else, perhaps by magic?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 加える. To help you distinguish between the two, remember that most verbs ending in わる are intransitive.

examples.en: My nostrils are itchy.
examples.ja: 鼻の穴が痒い。

examples.en: My head is itching because I haven't showered in a week.
examples.ja: 一週間シャワーを浴びてないから頭が痒い。

examples.en: I'm so itchy that I can't sleep at night, and I'm totally sleep-deprived.
examples.ja: 夜も寝れないぐらい痒くて、めっちゃ寝不足なんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is <kanji>itchy</kanji>, and the adjective version is <vocabulary>itchy</vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji: かゆ.

examples.en: I just arrived at the hotel where I will be staying during the business trip.
examples.ja: 今、出張先のホテルに着いたところだよ。

examples.en: During the business trip, I ate delicious food.
examples.ja: 出張先で、美味しい食べ物を食べた。

examples.en: My father is on an overseas business trip. He said that when business trips get prolonged, he misses his family.
examples.ja: 父は海外出張中なんです。出張が長引くと、家族が恋しくなると言っていました。

examples.en: Speaking of Nagoya, I've been there on a business trip. During the business trip, I was lucky to stay at a nice hotel.
examples.ja: 名古屋なら、出張で行ったことがあるよ。出張中、いいホテルに泊まれてラッキーだったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>exit</kanji> the building and <kanji>stretch</kanji> in preparation for your <vocabulary>business trip</vocabulary>. This is the routine you always follow for your business trips: exit, and stretch.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful about しゅつ becoming しゅっ here!

examples.en: The man worked at a gas station on the outskirts of town.
examples.ja: 男は町外れにあるガソリンスタンドで働いていた。

examples.en: I'm staying at a hotel on the outskirts of town, that doesn’t even have a convenience store nearby.
examples.ja: 近くにコンビニすらない町外れのホテルにステイしてるんだ。

examples.en: How did you get this far out of town?
examples.ja: こんな町外れまで、どうやって来たの？

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 町 means "town" and that 外れ can mean "periphery" or "outskirts." This is just a combination of the two, so it means the <vocabulary>outskirts of town</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You've already learned both 町 and 外れ, so just combine the two and you get 町外れ not only in meaning, but also in reading!

examples.en: The coming-of-age ceremony is an important milestone in one's life.
examples.ja: 成人式は、大切な人生の節目です。

examples.en: Then that year, something happened that would become a major turning point in my life.
examples.ja: そしてその年、人生の大きな節目になる出来事が起こったんです。

examples.en: In hindsight, I guess that was a critical juncture.
examples.ja: 今から思うと、あれが一つの節目だったんだろうね。

meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>season</kanji>s should you keep an <kanji>eye</kanji> on? The seasons that are <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary>s in your life. Keep an eye on those seasons, because you don't want to miss the <vocabulary>critical juncture</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji. You haven't learned that yet for 節, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The real <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary> in your life was when you got yourself a <reading>few she</reading>ep (ふし). Owning a few sheep was a true <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary> for you. Now you have all the wool sweaters and cheese you could ever want!

examples.en: I open the shutters every morning.
examples.ja: 毎朝、雨戸を開けます。

examples.en: Recently, there are fewer houses with shutters in Japan.
examples.ja: 最近は日本でも雨戸をつけている家が少なくなりました。

examples.en: I woke up in the middle of the night because of the sound of rain hitting the shutters.
examples.ja: 雨が雨戸を叩く音で深夜に起きてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>rain</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is really just a <vocabulary>shutter</vocabulary>. In Japan, having shutters for rain protection is very common. When there were no glass windows, the shutters were simply like exterior doors in Japan, so "rain door" kind of makes sense as "shutter"! 

This word is usually for <vocabulary>sliding storm shutter</vocabulary>s. For other types of shutters, you can just say シャッター.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, but it actually uses kun'yomi for both 雨 and 戸. Additionally, the reading for 雨 is actually slightly different from what you've learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

A <vocabulary>shutter</vocabulary> is basically just <reading>armor</reading> (あま) for a window. They're both protective, and are often made from metal. Kind of makes sense, right?

examples.en: I will make this dream come true no matter what!
examples.ja: ゼッタイにこの夢を叶えるんだ！

examples.en: When do you want to achieve that goal by?
examples.ja: あなたは、いつまでにその目標を叶えたいですか？

examples.en: It may not be possible to fulfill all your wishes.
examples.ja: 全ての希望を叶えることはできないかもしれません。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means "come true" or <kanji>grant</kanji>, and this is the transitive verb version of that, making this <vocabulary>to grant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fulfill</vocabulary>.

叶える refers to making something desired come true, either for oneself or someone else. It's usually used in the context of fulfilling wishes, dreams, or goals, but it can also be used for granting someone's request in more formal contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you already learned this with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: An inclination to learn on one's own is important.
examples.ja: 自ら学ぶ姿勢が大切なんです。

examples.en: Daily yoga is indispensable for my self-improvement.
examples.ja: 自らを高めるため、毎日ヨガは欠かせません。

examples.en: Say what you will, but you're the one who willingly ate the habanero, aren't you?
examples.ja: そんなこと言ったって、自ら進んでハバネロを食べたのは君だろう？

examples.en: It's rare for the president to personally apologize to a customer like that, huh.
examples.ja: 社長自らお客さんに謝るなんて珍しいね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji <kanji>self</kanji> is all by itself! So, naturally, this word means <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary>. Don't let the ら on the end confuse you, by the way — this word is singular.

Like 自分, 自ら means "oneself," but it's mostly used in formal or literary contexts. It can also be used as an adverb to mean <vocabulary>on one's own initiative</vocabulary> to emphasize voluntary action, or <vocabulary>personally</vocabulary> to highlight direct involvement — for example, 自ら辞める (to quit on one's own initiative) or 自ら謝る (to personally apologize).
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses 自's kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

If one prefers not to drive <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary>, a great alternative option is the 水-car (みずか). It's a self-driving car that runs entirely on 水, rather than gas, allowing one to fight climate change  <vocabulary>on one's own initiative</vocabulary> while never needing to <vocabulary>personally</vocabulary> take the wheel. Stop by your local dealership and get yourself a 水-car today!
